chapters.title: STATE BEFORE WORDS
chapters.content:
Before anything you text matters, your nervous system has already spoken.
Customers don't respond to your words first. They respond to your state.
If you are:
● Desperate for the set → they feel pressure
● Rushed → they feel urgency
● Anxious about quota → they feel manipulation
● Attached to outcome → they feel controlled
You must regulate yourself before you regulate the interaction.
THE PRE-RESPONSE CHECK
Before responding to any lead, run this protocol:
1. IS MY BREATHING SLOW?
Count: 4 seconds in, 6 seconds out. Three cycles minimum.
If your heart is racing, you're not ready.
2. IS MY BODY RELAXED?
Check:
● Jaw (unclenched?)
● Shoulders (dropped?)
● Hands (open, not gripping phone?)
● Stomach (soft, not tight?)
3. COULD I WALK AWAY FROM THIS LEAD WITHOUT RESENTMENT?
If the answer is no, you're too attached.
Wait. Breathe. Detach from outcome.
4. WHAT'S MY EMOTIONAL STATE?
High arousal (anxiety, excitement) → Wait until calm.
Low arousal (calm, confident) → Proceed.
IF YOU CAN'T REGULATE, DO NOT RESPOND YET
Texts sent from dysregulation always backfire.
Sometimes immediately. Sometimes later. But always eventually.
Your anxiety will seep through word choice, timing, and structure.
The lead's nervous system will detect it and activate defense.
THE STORY: THE LEAD I DESTROYED BECAUSE I WAS
DESPERATE
2019. Last day of the month. Two units short of bonus.
Lead comes in at 4:47pm on a high-margin F-150.
I NEED this set.
I respond in 34 seconds.
"Hi David! Thanks for your interest in the F-150! It's an awesome truck! When can you come see
it? We're open until 8pm tonight!"
My desperation is bleeding through every word.
Too fast. Too many exclamation points. Immediate appointment push.
He doesn't respond.
I follow up 90 minutes later.
"Hey David, just wanted to make sure you got my message! That truck is getting a lot of interest!
Would hate for you to miss it!"
More desperation. More pressure.
He never responds.
I lost a qualified buyer in two messages because I couldn't regulate myself.
WHAT I SHOULD HAVE DONE:
Recognized my state BEFORE responding.
I was anxious. Desperate. Attached to outcome.
I should have:
1. Taken 10 minutes to breathe
2. Reminded myself: "This lead is not my bonus. One lead does not define my month."
3. Detached from outcome
4. THEN responded
From that regulated state:
"Hi David—saw you were looking at the F-150. What made you start looking at trucks?"
Calm. Curious. No pressure.
Might have set the appointment.
Instead, my dysregulation killed it before it started.
THE DAILY REGULATION PRACTICE
If you're consistently responding from dysregulation, you need a daily practice.
Every morning before you start:
1. Five minutes of conscious breathing
○ 4 seconds in, 6 seconds out
○ Repeat 20 cycles
2. Set your intention
○ "Today I will guide appointments from calm, not desperation."
○ "Today I will respect every no as much as every yes."
○ "Today I will preserve my integrity above my numbers."
3. Review yesterday's dysregulated moments
○ Where did you push from anxiety?
○ Where did you pressure from desperation?
○ Where did you violate trust?
This isn't woo-woo. This is professional discipline.
The best internet managers regulate themselves first.
The average ones try to regulate customers while dysregulated themselves.
THE RULE:
State before strategy. Always.
If you skip this, everything else fails quietly.

chapters.title: THE REAL-TIME LOOP
chapters.content:
Mastery is not linear. It is loop-based.
You are constantly cycling through the three gates:
1. Threat Neutralization
2. Agency Preservation
3. Identity Alignment
When resistance appears, you do not push forward. You loop backward.
HOW THE LOOP WORKS
You're at Gate 2 (Agency). Resistance appears.
Your options:
Option A (Amateur): Push harder.
"Come on, just come in and check it out. What's the worst that could happen?"
Result: Resistance increases. Lead goes dark.
Option B (Practitioner): Stop. Diagnose. Loop back.
Ask yourself: "Which gate just closed?"
If it's Gate 1 (Threat), return there. Restore safety.
If it's Gate 2 (Agency), give back control.
If it's Gate 3 (Identity), help them recognize alignment.
When the earlier gate reopens, the system self-corrects.
You don't have to rebuild. You just have to re-calm.
RESISTANCE IS NOT FAILURE. IT IS DIAGNOSTIC DATA.
The moment you treat resistance as opposition instead of information, you lose authority.
Resistance tells you:
● Which gate closed
● What you missed
● Where to return
It's a gift—if you read it correctly.
THE STORY: THE TEXT THREAD I SAVED BY LOOPING
BACK
2021. Lead on a Civic. Great conversation for 6 messages.
Then I said: "Perfect. Want to come see it Tuesday or Wednesday?"
Her: "I need to think about it."
Gate 2 closed. Loss of control detected.
Amateur response: "What do you need to think about? I can answer any questions you have."
Translation: I'm not letting you escape. I'm trapping you.
My response:
"Of course. Take whatever time you need. Is there something specific you're trying to figure
out?"
I just gave control back.
Her (15 minutes later): "I guess I'm just not sure if I'm ready to commit to looking."
Now I see the real issue. It's not the car. It's the commitment to even LOOK.
Gate 3 issue (identity: "I don't make impulsive decisions").
Me: "That makes sense. Looking doesn't commit you to anything. Most people just want to see if
it matches what they're picturing from photos. Then they can decide from there."
Her: "That's true. Okay, Wednesday works."
Appointment set.
By looping back to Gate 2, I discovered the Gate 3 issue. Addressed it. Moved forward.
If I'd pushed at the resistance, she would have ghosted.
THE RULE FOR THE LOOP:
Resistance is not a wall. It's a signpost.
It's telling you where to go. Follow it.

chapters.title: WHEN TO STOP TEXTING
chapters.content:
Most failed interactions fail because the internet manager kept going.
There are three moments when you must stop messaging immediately:
MOMENT 1: PROCESSING SIGNALS APPEAR
What you see:
● They stop responding mid-conversation
● Last message was engaged, then silence
● They said "let me think about it" without defensiveness
What it means:
They're forming the decision internally.
What to do:
WAIT.
Do not follow up for 24-36 hours.
If you message during processing, you collapse the internal work they're doing.
MOMENT 2: INTERNAL YES APPEARS
What you see:
● Future-oriented language ("When I come in...")
● Logistical questions ("What should I bring?")
● Ownership language ("My appointment")
What it means:
The decision has formed. They're ready.
What to do:
STOP SELLING IMMEDIATELY.
Transition to logistics only.
"Perfect. I'll text you the address and my direct number."
What NOT to do:
Keep persuading. Add more benefits. Introduce new features.
This is the most common mistake. Someone reaches "yes" and the internet manager keeps
selling.
Result: Doubt enters. The yes unravels.
MOMENT 3: DEFENSIVE SIGNALS APPEAR
What you see:
● Short, clipped responses
● "Just send me the price"
● Long delays
● Energy shift from warm to cold
What it means:
A gate closed. Threat detected.
What to do:
STOP PUSHING.
Return to the gate that closed.
"Hey—I might be moving too fast here. What would be most helpful for you right now?"
Do NOT keep trying to set the appointment.
THE STORY: THE YES I DESTROYED BY TEXTING PAST
IT
2020. Lead on an Accord. Great conversation.
Him: "This looks perfect. What time can I come see it Thursday?"
INTERNAL YES.
I should have said: "Great—does afternoon or evening work better?"
Instead, I said:
"Awesome! Just to confirm you're seeing the full value here—this Accord also comes with a full
warranty and we'll include free oil changes for a year."
I kept selling past the yes.
His next message, 2 hours later: "Actually, let me think about this a bit more."
He never came in.
What happened:
He had decided. The sale was done.
Then I added more information. His brain interpreted it as:
"Why is he still convincing me? What am I missing? Is something wrong?"
Doubt entered. The yes collapsed.
THE RULE:
Texting past the yes is worse than never getting to yes.
Once they've decided, your job is done.
Stop. Confirm logistics. Execute.

chapters.title: THE NO-SHOW PREVENTION PROTOCOL
chapters.content:
The highest show rates come from four specific practices:
PRACTICE 1: THE CONFIRMATION TEXT (24 Hours
Before)
24 hours before the appointment:
"Hey [Name]—just confirming we're still on for tomorrow at [time]. Looking forward to meeting
you."
Why this works:
● Reminds them without pressure
● Gives them a chance to reschedule if needed
● Shows you're organized
If they don't respond within 4 hours:
"Hey [Name]—no worries if something came up. Just let me know if we need to reschedule."
PRACTICE 2: THE DAY-OF TEXT (Morning Of)
Morning of the appointment:
"Hey [Name]—looking forward to seeing you at [time] today. Text me when you're on your way
and I'll meet you out front."
Why this works:
● Creates accountability
● Reduces anxiety (you'll meet them)
● Makes it personal
PRACTICE 3: THE RUNNING-LATE GRACE
If they text they're running late:
"No problem at all. Take your time. I'll be here."
Never:
● Act annoyed
● Pressure them to hurry
● Make them feel guilty
Why:
One late customer is better than one no-show.
PRACTICE 4: THE IMMEDIATE NO-SHOW RESPONSE
If they no-show:
Wait 30 minutes past appointment time. Then text:
"Hey [Name]—totally understand if something came up. If you still want to see the [vehicle], I'm
here. No pressure either way."
Not:
"We had you down for an appointment. What happened?"
Why:
The first response preserves future relationship. The second destroys it.
THE STORY: THE NO-SHOW WHO BECAME A BUYER
2021. Customer no-showed a 6pm appointment.
6:45pm, I texted:
"Hey Marcus—no worries if something came up today. If you still want to see the Tacoma, I'm
here tomorrow or just let me know when works better. Zero pressure."
He responded 10pm:
"Man, I'm so sorry. Work emergency. Can I come tomorrow?"
Me: "Of course. Same time work?"
Him: "Yes. Thanks for understanding."
He came in the next day. Bought the truck.
If I'd made him feel guilty, he would have avoided me entirely.
Instead, I preserved Gate 2 (agency) and Gate 1 (safety).
He felt respected. He returned.
THE RULE FOR NO-SHOWS:
How you respond to a no-show determines whether you'll ever see them again.
Remove guilt. Preserve agency. Keep the door open.

chapters.title: THE ADVANCED DIAGNOSTIC SYSTEM
chapters.content:
At mastery level, you can diagnose which gate is closed from a single message.
Here's the diagnostic framework:
DIAGNOSTIC PATTERN 1: INFORMATION REQUEST
Message: "Just send me the price."
Surface reading: They want price.
Deep reading: Gate 1 is closed (threat).
Translation: "I don't trust you yet. I'm keeping distance by focusing on numbers."
Response:
"Of course. Before I send it over, just want to make sure I'm sending info on the right one. What
made you interested in this one?"
Goal: Open Gate 1 through recognition before giving price.
DIAGNOSTIC PATTERN 2: DEFLECTION
Message: "I'm just looking."
Surface reading: They're not serious.
Deep reading: Gate 1 is closed (threat).
Translation: "I'm protecting myself from sales pressure by appearing uninterested."
Response:
"No problem. Are you replacing something, or just seeing what's out there?"
Goal: Casual curiosity. No pressure. Opens Gate 1.
DIAGNOSTIC PATTERN 3: DELAY WITHOUT REASON
Message: "I need to think about it."
Surface reading: They're uncertain.
Deep reading: Gate 2 is closed (control).
Translation: "I feel pressured. I need to create distance and regain control."
Response:
"Of course. Take whatever time you need. Is there something specific you're trying to figure
out?"
Goal: Return agency. Invite them to articulate real concern.
DIAGNOSTIC PATTERN 4: EXTERNAL VALIDATION
Message: "I need to talk to my wife / friend / advisor."
Surface reading: They need permission.
Deep reading: Gate 3 is threatened (identity).
Translation: "I'm not confident in my own judgment. I need external validation to feel smart
about this."
Response:
"Makes sense. Most people want to make sure they're seeing this clearly. Once you've talked,
let me know if you have any questions."
Goal: Normalize the need for validation. Remove pressure.
DIAGNOSTIC PATTERN 5: SPEED CONCERN
Message: "This feels fast" or "I usually take more time."
Surface reading: They want to slow down.
Deep reading: Gate 3 is closed (identity: "I'm not impulsive").
Translation: "Coming in conflicts with my self-image as a careful, thoughtful person."
Response:
"That makes sense. Being thoughtful saves people from bad decisions. What would make this
feel thoughtful instead of rushed?"
Goal: Validate identity, then help them see how appointment aligns with it.
THE DIAGNOSTIC QUESTION
When you're unsure which gate closed, ask:
"Help me understand—what specifically concerns you about coming in?"
Their answer will reveal the gate:
● If they mention pressure, sales tactics, or being tricked → Gate 1
● If they mention not being ready, needing time, or losing control → Gate 2
● If they mention being careful, doing research, or their usual process → Gate 3
Then address that specific gate.
THE RULE FOR DIAGNOSTICS:
Never respond to surface objections. Always respond to the underlying gate.
Treating symptoms doesn't work. Diagnose the source.

chapters.title: THE MULTI-LEAD PRESSURE PROBLEM
chapters.content:
You're managing 30+ active leads at once.
The temptation: rush through conversations to "touch" everyone.
The result: you destroy every interaction through speed.
THE QUALITY VS. QUANTITY TRAP
Amateur thinking:
"I need to respond to all 30 leads immediately. Speed to lead!"
Result:
● Generic responses
● Copy-paste energy
● Dysregulated state
● Low engagement
● High unsubscribe rate
Practitioner thinking:
"I will respond to 10 leads exceptionally well today. The rest can wait 30 minutes."
Result:
● Personalized responses
● Calm, regulated state
● High engagement
● Better conversion
THE DAILY LEAD PRIORITIZATION SYSTEM
Every morning, categorize your leads:
TIER 1: HOT (Respond within 10-15 minutes)
● Requested appointment
● Asked specific logistical questions
● Replied to your last message with engagement
TIER 2: WARM (Respond within 30-45 minutes)
● New leads from last 24 hours
● Mid-conversation but not urgent
● Follow-ups you scheduled
TIER 3: COLD (Respond within 2-4 hours)
● Initial follow-ups on older leads
● Informational requests with no urgency
● Leads you're nurturing long-term
Process Tier 1 first. Then Tier 2. Then Tier 3.
Never try to touch everyone at once.
THE BATCH RESPONSE PROTOCOL
Set specific times to respond to leads:
● 9:00am - 10:00am: Tier 1 & 2
● 12:00pm - 1:00pm: Tier 2 & 3
● 4:00pm - 5:00pm: Tier 1 & 2
● 7:00pm - 7:30pm: Final Tier 1 check
Between these times:
Step away from the inbox. Do other work. Regulate yourself.
Why this works:
Constant inbox monitoring creates:
● Anxiety
● Reactive responses
● Dysregulation
● Burnout
Batched responses create:
● Calm
● Thoughtful responses
● Regulation
● Sustainability
THE STORY: WHEN I CUT MY LEAD VOLUME AND
DOUBLED MY SETS
2020. I was working 50+ leads at once.
My set rate: 38%.
My show rate: 41%.
I was drowning. Every response felt rushed. I was copying and pasting. I was burning out.
Then I changed the system.
New rule: Maximum 25 active leads at once.
If I hit 25, I stop accepting new assignments until leads convert or age out.
Result:
● Set rate: 54%
● Show rate: 76%
● Stress level: Cut in half
● Job satisfaction: Doubled
Why:
I could give each lead real attention. Personalized responses. Calm state.
Quality > Quantity. Always.
THE RULE FOR MULTI-LEAD MANAGEMENT:
You cannot serve 50 leads well. You can serve 20 leads exceptionally.
Choose quality. Always.

chapters.title: MANAGER PRESSURE VS. CUSTOMER
chapters.content:
TRUST
Your manager wants speed, volume, and set rate.
Your customer wants calm, respect, and safety.
These are often in conflict.
How do you navigate this?
THE HONEST CONVERSATION WITH MANAGEMENT
At some point, you need to have this conversation:
"I can hit 70% set rate with 40% show rate, or 50% set rate with 80% show rate. Which do
you want?"
Most managers will say: "I want both."
Your response:
"I understand. But here's the reality: high set rates come from pressure. High show rates come
from trust. Pressure and trust are inversely related. We have to choose."
If they insist on high set rate regardless of show rate:
You have two options:
Option A: Comply. Use pressure. Hit set numbers. Accept high no-show rate. Burn out in 18
months.
Option B: Find a dealership that values long-term customer relationships over short-term
metrics.
THE MIDDLE PATH: TRANSPARENT METRICS
Propose tracking both metrics transparently:
● Set rate
● Show rate
● Effective set rate (sets × show rate)
Example:
Internet Manager A:
● Set rate: 75%
● Show rate: 35%
● Effective set rate: 26.25%
Internet Manager B (You):
● Set rate: 52%
● Show rate: 78%
● Effective set rate: 40.56%
Who's actually more effective?
You are. By a lot.
But if management only tracks set rate, Manager A looks better.
Effective set rate reveals the truth.
THE STORY: THE MANAGER WHO FINALLY SAW THE
LIGHT
2019. My manager was on me constantly.
"Your set rate is 48%. Everyone else is at 65%+. What's wrong?"
Me: "What's our show rate?"
Him: "That's not the point. We need more appointments."
Me: "Okay. Can you track show rate by internet manager for one month?"
He agreed reluctantly.
End of month:
My stats:
● Set rate: 51%
● Show rate: 79%
● Effective sets: 40.29%
Top set-rate person:
● Set rate: 71%
● Show rate: 31%
● Effective sets: 22.01%
Manager: "Holy shit. You're crushing everyone."
From that point forward, he stopped pressuring me about set rate.
He started asking the others: "Why is your show rate so low?"
THE RULE FOR MANAGER PRESSURE:
Educate with data. If they won't listen, find a better dealership.
You cannot serve two masters: quota and integrity.
Choose integrity. The right dealership will value it.

chapters.title: SELF-CORRECTION WITHOUT
chapters.content:
SUPERVISION
The final stage of mastery is internal.
You no longer ask: "How do I set this appointment?"
You ask: "Should I?"
WHAT THIS LOOKS LIKE
You feel misalignment before action.
Mid-text thread, you sense: "This isn't right. I'm pushing."
You stop. Mid-message if necessary.
You correct yourself in real-time:
"Actually, let me back up. I don't want to rush you. How are you feeling about all this?"
You withdraw without drama:
"You know what, I don't think I'm the right person for this. Here's why. And here's who might be
better."
THE INTERNAL COMPASS
At this stage, the system becomes instinct—not strategy.
You don't think: "Which gate is this? What technique applies?"
You feel: "Something's off. Return to safety."
That's mastery.
THE STORY: THE MOMENT I BECAME A PRACTITIONER
2022. Lead on a fully-loaded Yukon. High margin. Big commission.
Great conversation. Everything was working.
They were engaged. Asking questions. Moving toward yes.
Then, mid-conversation, I felt it:
"This doesn't feel right."
I couldn't name why. But something was off.
I stopped.
"Hey—can I be honest? Something feels misaligned here, and I can't put my finger on it. Before
we go further, can you tell me: why are you really buying this?"
Long pause.
Him: "Because my wife wants it. Honestly, I think it's too expensive and we don't need it. But she
won't let it go."
There it was.
If I'd kept going, I would have set an appointment for someone who didn't want the vehicle.
His wife would have pushed him into the purchase. He would have resented it. They would have
returned it or left a 1-star review.
Instead, I said: "Then you shouldn't buy it. Not yet. Figure out if YOU want it first. If you do, call
me. If you don't, that's fine too."
He thanked me. Hung up.
Three weeks later, he called back.
"We talked. I'm actually excited about it now. Can I come in?"
He came in. Bought the Yukon. Perfect CSI score. Referred his brother.
If I'd ignored my instinct and pushed, I would have created a nightmare.
THE RULE:
Trust your instinct. It's trained now.
If something feels off, it is off—even if you can't articulate why.
Stop. Investigate. Correct.
That's the difference between technique and mastery.
END OF PART III
You now have real-time mastery:
● State before words
● The real-time loop
● When to stop texting
● The no-show prevention protocol
● The advanced diagnostic system
● Multi-lead pressure management
● Manager pressure navigation
● Self-correction without supervision
In Part IV, we move to integration:
How to build a department that operates this way.
How to train others in this system.
How to maintain integrity under pressure.
How KPIs must change to support this approach.
PART IV: DEPARTMENT INTEGRATION

chapters.title: BUILDING A TRUST-BASED DEPARTMENT
chapters.content:
If you're the only one operating this way, you'll hit a ceiling.
The rest of the department will undermine you—not intentionally, but structurally.
To scale this approach, you must build it into the department.
THE THREE-LEVEL INTEGRATION
LEVEL 1: INDIVIDUAL MASTERY
You master the system personally.
Outcome: Your numbers improve. Your stress decreases.
LEVEL 2: TEAM ADOPTION
You train others. 2-3 people adopt the system.
Outcome: Pod performance improves. Culture shifts slightly.
LEVEL 3: DEPARTMENTAL TRANSFORMATION
Leadership adopts it. Metrics change. Training changes. Hiring changes.
Outcome: Entire department operates from trust, not pressure.
HOW TO MOVE FROM LEVEL 1 TO LEVEL 2
STEP 1: DOCUMENT YOUR RESULTS
Track for 90 days:
● Set rate
● Show rate
● Effective set rate (sets × show rate)
● Customer satisfaction scores
● Referral rate
Compare to department average.
When your effective set rate is 1.5x-2x higher, you have leverage.
STEP 2: SHARE THE SYSTEM (NOT AS CRITICISM)
Don't say: "Everyone else is doing it wrong."
Say: "I've been experimenting with a different approach. Want to see the results?"
Show data, not theory.
STEP 3: OFFER TO TRAIN ONE PERSON
Find someone who:
● Is struggling with no-shows
● Feels burned out from pressure tactics
● Is open to new approaches
Offer to mentor them for 30 days.
THE 30-DAY MENTORSHIP PROTOCOL
WEEK 1: ARCHITECTURE ONLY
Teach:
● The Three Gates
● How decisions actually happen
● Why pressure backfires
No tactics yet. Just understanding.
WEEK 2: FIRST MESSAGE & FOLLOW-UP
Teach:
● First message formula
● Text sequencing
● Follow-up without pressure
Review every message they send. Provide real-time feedback.
WEEK 3: DIAGNOSTICS
Teach:
● Reading resistance
● Diagnosing which gate closed
● Looping back
Shadow their conversations. Point out what you see.
WEEK 4: INTEGRATION
They operate independently. You review weekly.
Goal: They internalize the system without needing supervision.
THE STORY: THE REP I TRAINED WHO BECAME BETTER
THAN ME
2021. New hire—let's call her Maria.
She'd worked at three dealerships. Burned out every time. Hated "selling."
I offered to train her differently.
She was skeptical but willing.
Week 1: I taught her the Three Gates. No tactics.
She said: "This explains why I always felt gross using the old methods."
Week 2: I reviewed every text she sent. Made small corrections.
Her set rate: 41%. Show rate: 68%.
Week 3: She started diagnosing resistance on her own.
Her set rate: 48%. Show rate: 74%.
Week 4: She was operating independently.
Her set rate: 53%. Show rate: 81%.
Six months later:
Her set rate: 58%. Show rate: 84%. Effective set rate: 48.72%.
Mine at the time: Set rate: 54%. Show rate: 78%. Effective set rate: 42.12%.
She surpassed me.
Why? Because she started with a clean slate. No bad habits to unlearn.
She became the best internet manager in our region.
THE RULE FOR TEAM ADOPTION:
Train one person exceptionally well. Their results will recruit others.
Don't try to convert everyone at once. That creates resistance.
Start with one. Build from there.

chapters.title: THE METRIC REVOLUTION
chapters.content:
If leadership still only tracks set rate, this system will be penalized.
You must change what gets measured.
THE FOUR METRICS THAT MATTER
METRIC 1: EFFECTIVE SET RATE
Formula: Set Rate × Show Rate
Why it matters: This is the REAL conversion rate.
70% set rate with 30% show rate = 21% effective.
50% set rate with 80% show rate = 40% effective.
The second is nearly 2x more effective.
METRIC 2: CUSTOMER SATISFACTION (CSI)
How to track: Post-visit survey scores.
Why it matters: High-pressure sets create low satisfaction. Trust-based sets create high
satisfaction.
METRIC 3: REFERRAL RATE
Formula: Number of referrals ÷ Number of sales
Why it matters: Customers who were pressured don't refer. Customers who were respected
do.
METRIC 4: LONG-TERM RELATIONSHIP VALUE
Formula: Repeat purchases + referrals + service retention
Why it matters: One customer becomes 3-5 transactions over 10 years if trust is maintained.
THE PITCH TO LEADERSHIP
Schedule a meeting with your manager or GM.
Say this:
"I want to propose tracking four metrics instead of just set rate. Here's why:
Our current system rewards appointments that don't show. We're inflating set numbers with
low-quality appointments.
If we track effective set rate, CSI, referrals, and long-term value, we'll optimize for what actually
drives profit: customers who show up, buy, and refer.
Can we pilot this with my leads for 90 days and compare to the current system?"
If they say yes: You just changed the game.
If they say no: You're at the wrong dealership.
THE STORY: THE DEALERSHIP THAT TRANSFORMED
2020. I pitched this metric system to my GM.
He was skeptical.
"Set rate has worked for 20 years. Why change now?"
Me: "Because customers have changed. They have unlimited information. They can smell
pressure from a mile away. Our no-show rate is 58%. That means we're wasting everyone's
time."
Him: "Fine. 90 days. But if your numbers drop, we go back."
90 days later:
My stats:
● Effective set rate: 43% (up from 28%)
● CSI: 4.8/5.0 (up from 4.1)
● Referral rate: 31% (up from 12%)
Department average:
● Effective set rate: 24%
● CSI: 4.2/5.0
● Referral rate: 8%
GM: "How do we train everyone to do this?"
That dealership is now the top-rated dealership in the region on Google (4.7 stars, 2,400+
reviews).
Their internet department has an 82% show rate.
They changed what they measured. Everything else followed.
THE RULE FOR METRICS:
What gets measured gets optimized.
If you measure set rate, you'll get pressure tactics.
If you measure effective set rate, CSI, and referrals, you'll get trust-based selling.
Change the metrics. Change the system.

chapters.title: THE HIRING FILTER
chapters.content:
If you're hiring internet managers, most candidates will be wrong for this system.
You need a hiring filter that selects for the right attributes.
THE THREE ATTRIBUTES THAT PREDICT SUCCESS
ATTRIBUTE 1: EMOTIONAL REGULATION
Can they stay calm under pressure?
Can they detach from outcome?
Can they handle rejection without defensiveness?
Test this in the interview:
"Tell me about a time you lost a deal you really wanted. How did you handle it emotionally?"
Green flag answer: "I was disappointed, but I reminded myself that not every deal is meant to
be. I focused on learning from it."
Red flag answer: "I was furious. The customer was making a mistake and I couldn't convince
them."
ATTRIBUTE 2: EMPATHY WITHOUT ATTACHMENT
Can they understand customer concerns without taking them personally?
Can they see the customer's perspective?
Test this in the interview:
"Imagine a customer says 'I need to think about it' after you've spent 30 minutes texting. What's
going through their mind?"
Green flag answer: "They might feel pressured. Or they might legitimately need time to
process. I'd ask what specifically they want to think through."
Red flag answer: "They're stalling. They're not serious. I'd push harder."
ATTRIBUTE 3: PATIENCE WITH PROCESS
Can they trust a system that feels slower upfront?
Can they delay gratification?
Test this in the interview:
"Would you rather set 10 appointments with 30% show rate, or 6 appointments with 85% show
rate?"
**Green flag
Continue
3:04 PM
answer:** "Six with 85%. Quality over quantity."
Red flag answer: "Ten. More chances to close."
THE INTERVIEW QUESTION THAT REVEALS
EVERYTHING
"Why do you think customers don't show for appointments?"
Green flag answer: "Usually because they felt pressured or the appointment was set before
they were ready. The salesperson pushed too hard."
Red flag answer: "Because customers are flaky. They don't value our time."
The first answer shows empathy and systems thinking.
The second shows victim mentality and blame.
THE STORY: THE HIRE WHO TRANSFORMED OUR
DEPARTMENT
2021. We were hiring an internet manager.
Candidate—let's call him James—had worked at two dealerships. Average numbers. Nothing
special.
In the interview, I asked: "What frustrates you most about internet sales?"
Him: "Honestly? The pressure to set appointments with people who aren't ready. I've had
managers yelling at me for not hitting set rate, but half my appointments no-show. It feels like a
waste of everyone's time."
Green flag.
Me: "What would you do differently if you could?"
Him: "I'd slow down. Build actual trust. Make sure people really want to come in before setting
the appointment."
Double green flag.
We hired him.
Six months later:
● Effective set rate: 47%
● CSI: 4.9/5.0
● Zero customer complaints
● Highest referral rate in department
He was already aligned with the system. We just gave him permission to use it.
THE RULE FOR HIRING:
Hire for attributes, train for skills.
You can teach the Three Gates. You cannot teach emotional regulation or empathy.
Select for character. Train for craft.

chapters.title: THE TRAINING PROGRAM
chapters.content:
If you're training a team, you need a structured program.
Here's the 12-week curriculum that works:
WEEKS 1-2: ARCHITECTURE
Core concepts:
● How appointment decisions actually happen
● The Three Gates
● Why pressure backfires
● Emotional state hierarchy
Practice:
● Shadow experienced practitioner
● Watch 10 text threads (successful and failed)
● Document: What did you notice?
No live leads yet.** Just observation.
WEEKS 3-4: FIRST MESSAGES
Core concepts:
● First message formula
● Response timing
● Opening Gate 1
● When NOT to respond
Practice:
● Write 20 first messages
● Get feedback on each
● Revise until patterns internalize
Still no live leads.** Simulated only.
WEEKS 5-6: CONVERSATION SEQUENCING
Core concepts:
● Text sequence patterns
● Moving through gates
● Reading resistance
● When to stop
Practice:
● Role-play full conversations
● Trainer plays customer with different resistance types
● Trainee practices diagnosing and looping back
Begin taking live leads under supervision.**
WEEKS 7-8: PHONE CALLS
Core concepts:
● When to call vs. text
● Phone call architecture
● Transitioning from text to voice
● Reading vocal resistance
Practice:
● Shadow 10 live phone calls
● Take 5 calls with trainer listening
● Debrief each one
WEEKS 9-10: FOLLOW-UP
Core concepts:
● Follow-up ladder
● Persistence without pressure
● When to stop following up
● Nurture sequences
Practice:
● Manage 10 cold leads
● Document follow-up approach
● Review with trainer
WEEKS 11-12: INTEGRATION
Core concepts:
● Managing multiple leads simultaneously
● Daily prioritization
● State management under pressure
● Self-correction
Practice:
● Full lead load
● Weekly reviews with trainer
● Monthly check-ins after certification
THE CERTIFICATION TEST
After 12 weeks, the trainee must demonstrate:
1. Architecture Knowledge
Explain the Three Gates and when each typically closes.
2. Diagnostic Ability
Read 5 text threads and diagnose which gate is closed in each resistance point.
3. Real Performance
● Minimum 45% effective set rate over 30 days
● Minimum 4.5/5.0 CSI scores
● Zero customer complaints
If they pass all three: Certified.
If not: Another 30 days of practice.
THE RULE FOR TRAINING:
Go slow to go fast.
12 weeks feels long. But a properly trained internet manager will outperform for years.
A rushed 2-week training creates mediocrity that lasts just as long.
Invest in training. It pays forever.

chapters.title: THE ETHICS UNDER PRESSURE
chapters.content:
You will face moments where pressure tempts you to violate the system.
End of month. One unit short of bonus. High-value lead comes in.
The temptation: Push harder. Close at all costs.
THE PRE-VIOLATION WARNING SIGNS
You'll know you're about to violate when you think:
"They need this. I'm helping them by pushing."
Translation: I'm rationalizing pressure as service.
"If I don't set this now, I'll lose them."
Translation: I'm prioritizing my outcome over their readiness.
"This is different. This one time it's okay."
Translation: I'm creating exceptions to avoid accountability.
THE INTERVENTION PROTOCOL
When you notice these thoughts, STOP.
Run this check:
1. Am I attached to outcome?
If yes: Breathe. Detach. Remember that one lead is not your month.
2. Am I dysregulated?
If yes: Step away. Regulate. Come back when calm.
3. Would I guide this decision the same way if I couldn't benefit?
If no: Step back or walk away.
4. Is this a grounded yes or compliance yes?
If compliance: Pause and give space.
THE STORY: THE BONUS I SACRIFICED FOR INTEGRITY
2021. Last day of month. Two units short of $3,000 bonus.
Lead comes in on a high-margin SUV at 7:48pm.
I respond. Great conversation. Gates opening.
By 8:30pm, I could set the appointment.
But something felt off.
She was agreeing too quickly. Nervous laughter. Over-compliance.
Compliance yes.
I should have pushed anyway. It was $3,000.
Instead, I said:
"Hey—before we lock this in, I want to make sure you feel completely solid about coming in
tomorrow. Does this feel right to you, or are you feeling rushed?"
Pause.
Her: "Honestly, it does feel a little fast. I think I need another day to think."
Me: "No problem at all. Take your time. Text me when you're ready."
She texted me three days later. Came in. Bought the SUV.
I sacrificed the bonus.
But I kept my integrity.
And that customer referred two people within 60 days.
The bonus was $3,000. The referrals were worth $4,200 in commission.
Integrity paid more than manipulation.
THE RULE FOR ETHICS UNDER PRESSURE:
Short-term pressure is not an excuse for long-term violation.
If you cannot hit your numbers without pressure, your numbers are wrong—not your ethics.
Sacrifice the bonus. Keep your integrity.

chapters.title: THE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY
chapters.content:
This system is not a sprint. It's a career framework.
If you operate this way for 5-10 years, here's what happens:
YEAR 1: DISCOVERY
You learn the system. Your numbers stabilize. Stress decreases.
YEAR 2-3: MASTERY
The system becomes instinct. You diagnose instantly. You regulate automatically.
YEAR 4-5: REPUTATION
Your referral rate climbs. Customers ask for you by name. Your CSI is consistently 4.8+.
YEAR 6-10: AUTHORITY
You train others. You consult for other dealerships. You build a department around trust.

Traditional pressure-based internet managers:
● Year 1: 100 sales, 5 referrals
● Year 2: 100 sales, 5 referrals
● Year 3: 100 sales, 5 referrals

The trust-based manager does 20% more volume—entirely from referrals and repeat
customers.
THE STORY: THE CAREER I BUILT ON TRUST
2016-2026. Ten years in internet sales.
Year 1: Learned the hard way. Burned leads with pressure.
Year 3: Adopted this system. Numbers stabilized.
Year 5: Top performer in region. 4.9 CSI. 40% referral rate.
Year 7: Promoted to internet manager. Trained 12 people in this system.
Year 10: Consultant for three dealership groups. Speaking at conferences.
Total career sales: 1,847 vehicles.
Total referrals: 623.
Average commission per deal: $450.
Total earnings: $831,150.
I built a career—not on pressure, but on trust.
And I never once felt like I violated someone.
THE RULE FOR SUSTAINABILITY:
This system doesn't just work. It lasts.
Pressure burns you out in 3-5 years.
Trust builds a 20-year career.
Choose accordingly.

chapters.title: THE FINAL TRUTH
chapters.content:
You now have the complete system.
It works because it's not fighting human neurobiology—it's working with it.
But here's what I need you to understand:
This system is not the point.
The point is becoming someone who:
● Sees clearly
● Acts ethically
● Respects autonomy
● Chooses restraint
The techniques are tools. The character is the goal.
You could forget every framework in this book and still be a master—if you've internalized the
ethics.
You could execute every technique flawlessly and still fail—if you've abandoned integrity.
The system is a vehicle. The destination is wisdom.
HERE'S MY FINAL QUESTION FOR YOU:
Not "Will you master this system?"
But "What kind of internet manager will you become?"
Someone who sets for numbers—or someone who sets for trust?
Someone who optimizes for set rate—or someone who optimizes for long-term relationships?
Someone who uses skill to pressure customers—or someone who uses skill to serve them?
Someone who proves mastery through what they close—or someone who proves mastery
through what they decline?
The choice is yours.
But choose consciously.
Because once you master this system, you cannot claim ignorance.
You will know—always—when you're pressuring someone.
You will know—always—when you're rationalizing.
You will know—always—when restraint is correct.
The question is not whether you'll know.
The question is whether you'll act on what you know.
EPILOGUE: TEN YEARS LATER
I'm writing this in year ten of practicing this system.
I've set thousands of appointments.
I've walked away from hundreds of opportunities.
I've pressured. I've corrected. I've rebuilt integrity more times than I can count.
Here's what I know now that I didn't know at the beginning:
1. The temptation never stops being dangerous.
Year one or year ten—it's always one rationalization away from pressure.
2. Restraint never gets easier.
Walking away from high-value leads still costs. The math doesn't change.
3. The internet managers who last are the ones who build accountability
early.
The ones who try to govern themselves alone always corrupt eventually.
4. Mastery is measured by what you decline, not what you close.
I'm most proud of the leads I let go.
5. The system is only as ethical as the practitioner.
Techniques are neutral. Character is everything.
6. You will pressure someone. The question is whether you'll admit it.
I've pressured more times than I've admitted publicly. But I've admitted it to my manager every
time.
7. The daily regulation practice saved me repeatedly.
The days I skipped it were the days I violated someone.
8. Teaching others is harder than practicing yourself.
Watching someone start to pressure is brutal—especially when they can't see it yet.
9. The metrics revolution is real.
Effective set rate changed everything at every dealership that adopted it.
10. The burden is worth it.
Despite everything—the temptations, the failures, the sacrifices—this has been the most
meaningful work of my career.
Not because I've set appointments.
Because I've learned restraint.
MY FINAL ADVICE:
Go slowly.
Build accountability early.
Document everything.
Stop when you should.
Walk away cleanly.
Feel the weight always.
And remember:
The highest form of mastery is choosing not to set the appointment.
Power proves itself most clearly when it is not used.
Welcome to the practice.
May you wield it wisely.
